abstract.text: Descriptive traits used to discover accessories.

inlineContent.text: Use an instance of this type to identify accessories your app can set up, then set it as the
Some of the Bluetooth identifier properties work together to filter matching accessories, as described in the following table.
Provide at least one UUID or manufacturer ID to filter.
Provide a name substring to look for.  Requires setting at least a service UUID or company ID, which identifies the service or company using the name.
When using manufacturer data filters, provide both the data and mask. These properties should have the same length and be less than or equal to the size of the advertised payload. The
identifies the manufacturer associated with the data.
When using UUID service data filters, provide both the data and mask. These properties should have the same length and be less than or equal to the size of the advertised payload. The
identifies the service associated with the data.
The descriptor also allows you to set the
of matched accessories; set its value to
to limit discovery of Bluetooth accessories to those within the immediate proximity of the device running your app.

discovering-configuring-accessories-Page.alt: An illustration that shows Bluetooth and Wi-Fi devices communicating.

abstract.text: Enable privacy-preserving discovery and configuration of accessories.
Options of discoverable accessories.
Properties of an event encountered during accessory discovery.
An enumeration of the types of events encountered during accessory discovery
The identifier of a Bluetooth accessory provider.
Descriptive traits used to discover accessories.
The Bluetooth range in which to discover accessories.
A range in the immediate vicinity of the device performing accessory discovery.
The accessory’s 16-bit Bluetooth Company Identifier.
A byte buffer that matches the accessory’s Bluetooth manufacturer data.
The accessory’s Bluetooth manufacturer data mask.
The accessory’s over-the-air Bluetooth name substring.
The accessory’s over-the-air Bluetooth name substring compare options.
A property that tells the session to discover accessories within a specific Bluetooth range.
A byte buffer that matches the accessory’s Bluetooth service data.
The accessory’s Bluetooth service data mask.
The accessory’s Bluetooth service UUID.
The SSID of the accessory’s Wi-Fi network.
The prefix string of SSID of the accessory’s Wi-Fi network.
Options supported by an accessory.
An accessory as presented by the discovery picker.
A descriptor that the picker uses to determine which discovered accessories to display.
Detect nearby accessories and facilitate their setup.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
